item.title: Amira add a quote by Charles Darwin
item.description: "If I had my life to live over again, I would have made a rule to read some poetry and listen to some music at least once every week." -- Charles Darwin

item.title: Amira add a quote by Edgar Allan Poe
item.description: "Deep in earth my love is lying And I must weep alone." -- Edgar Allan Poe

item.title: Amira add a quote by Sylvia Plath
item.description:
"Eternity bores me, I never wanted it.
From the poem "Years", 16 November 1962" -- Sylvia Plath

item.title: Amira add a quote by Bertrand Russell
item.description: "Love is wise; hatred is foolish. In this world, which is getting more and more closely interconnected, we have to learn to tolerate each other, we have to learn to put up with the fact that some people say things that we don't like. We can only live together in that way. But if we are to live together, and not die together, we must learn a kind of charity and a kind of tolerance, which is absolutely vital to the continuation of human life on this planet." -- Bertrand Russell

item.title: Amira add a quote by Gertrude Stein
item.description: "Let me listen to me and not to them." -- Gertrude Stein

item.title: Amira add a quote by Gertrude Stein
item.description: "Writing and reading is to me synonymous with existing. " -- Gertrude Stein

item.title: Amira add a quote by Elizabeth Gilbert
item.description: "To lose balance sometimes for love is part of living a balanced life." -- Elizabeth Gilbert

item.title: Amira add a quote by Judith Lewis Herman
item.description:
"Many abused children cling to the hope that growing up will bring escape and freedom.
But the personality formed in the environment of coercive control is not well adapted to adult life. The survivor is left with fundamental problems in basic trust, autonomy, and initiative. She approaches the task of early adulthood――establishing independence and intimacy――burdened by major impairments in self-care, in cognition and in memory, in identity, and in the capacity to form stable relationships.
She is still a prisoner of her childhood; attempting to create a new life, she reencounters the trauma." -- Judith Lewis Herman
